6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
POET's management and operations team is committed to an ongoing system of production process review, evaluation of improvements in available technology (including safety features), analysis of previous plant incidents (including near misses), safety SPOT (Safety Procedure Observation Tool) checks, and Prevention Program compliance audits, to identify opportunities to improve plant safety. At the time of this submission, there are no current design projects or equipment procurements planned to improve safety.

e any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change. 

Incident Investigation
POET has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.

Compliance Audits
The facility conducts audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The audits include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.

4.	Five-Year Accident History
The facility has an excellent record concerning minimizing recordable and reportable accidents. There have been no accidents at the facility that require inclusion in the five-year accident history as required by the RMP regulations.

5.	Emergency Response Program
POET maintains a written emergency response program in its EAP. The purpose of the EAP is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. In the event of a chemical emergency, POETs Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release. The emergency action plan addresses aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a

limit releases.

POET keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility. The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, piping and instrument drawings.

Operating Procedures and Training
POET maintains written procedures that address all modes of process operations, including normal operations, manual operation, and emergency shutdown. The facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.

Contractors
The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities in order to assure that the contractor's employees follow safe work practices and procedures. The procedure includes a contractor screening process and hazard awareness, safety and emergency procedures training.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
POET conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.

Mechanical Integrity
The facility's mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, and regular inspections and equipment testing procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems, and controls in a safe operating condition.

Management of Change
The facility's management of change (MOC) program reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manag

rom the bioethanol process is captured and then condensed using anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is the only RMP-regulated chemical that exceeds the quantity thresholds for the applicability of the regulation. 

3.	Accidental Release Prevention Program, and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
POET Biorefining - Macon is committed to the protection of the environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, passive mitigation, employee training, and response preparation. Computer based maintenance software is utilized to implement automatic scheduling and work order generation for covered process preventative maintenance inspections and monitoring. The POET facility is staffed year-round, 24 hours per day. The facility is lighted and access-controlled. Ammonia alarms have been installed and are monitored to detect an ammonia release. The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal conditions, which trigger visual alarm lights on the alarm system control panel. Both visual control panel alarm lights and audible alarms in the control room are sounded in the event of a release.
Employee Participation
POET has developed an employee participation program. All process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, and action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information
The facility utilizes the PHA Lite methodology. The PHA identified the following potential major hazards: toxic release, fire, explosion, over pressurization, corrosion, overfilling, contamination, equipment failure, loss of cooling, heating, electricity, instrument air and tornados. The facility utilizes process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shutoffs, interlocks, alarms and procedures and grounding equipment to prevent or

This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the POET Biorefining  Macon (POET) bioethanol production facility located approximately 4 miles east of Macon, Missouri. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. POET is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance above threshold quantities.

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
POET is committed to the protection of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment from industrial materials used in the bioethanol production process. Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel, POET has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from the release of hazardous materials.

The facility relies on outside services, LEPC, Fire, and Police to respond to major release events. If a release does occur, the facility's emergency response is described in its emergency action plan (EAP) developed per 29 CFR 1910.38(a). It is the policy of POET to notify the Macon Fire Department, evacuate or shelter-in-place all employees at the facility, and provide technical and logistic support to the Fire Department Incident Commander.

2.	Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
